However, I think the original spec is concentrating on its goal better."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-01-08 10:59:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28:

Summary of the IRC discussion (no final agreement, just the ideas):

1) instance_network_data duplicates the network_data argument to the provisioning API

2) we can use Glean on the ramdisk side, it has zero dependencies and is designed specifically to apply network configuration in the network_data format

3) since Glean does not define the exact subset of network_data it supports, it has to be defined, documented and ideally validated on input (because the cost of validation is negligible but the cost of a mistake is very high)

4) rescue seems problematic because it switches networks while the ramdisk is running; we can only support single-network rescue in this iteration, but it will remain a TODO

5) no consensus of splitting the network_data format into more granular fields, we'll probably accept it as it is"}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2020-01-08 11:22:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28:

(1 comment)

One of the themes of this discussion revolves around ironic conductor <-> Glean marriage. Two options came up related to this:

A) Built network_data.json validation into ironic conductor
B) Have the operator using a new tool of ours that will validate network_data.json prior to feeding it to ironic conductor.

In that light, it seems that (5) is related to the validation part of (3) - if we go for (5), then (3) is definitely a way to go.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-01-08 11:53:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28:

> One of the themes of this discussion revolves around ironic conductor <-> Glean marriage. Two options came up related to this

You're looking at this from a slightly wrong angle and keep coming to slightly biased conclusions. Looks from the consumers perspective. They don't care which backend we use for a feature, they only see the API. The API has to be usable, documented and consistent.

What we absolutely cannot do is say "we use something called glean as a backend, we don't know what it accepts, go look at it sources". This is not API, nor is it a ready-to-use feature. No matter how we implement this feature, we need to be clear on the accepted input.

Relying on client-side validation is a well-known anti-pattern and will cause immediate practical problems as well. So, say, we write it in Python. Metal3 will use it from a Go service in a container without Python.

Also, you still haven't mentioned what you're trying to win by moving the validation code to the client side. It won't be less code. It won't release us from backward compatibility concerns. It won't relief us from documenting the API and the format we accept. It won't make the backend choice discussion simpler. What's the point?'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2020-01-08 12:33:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28:

> What we absolutely cannot do is say "we use something called glean as a backend, we don't know what it accepts, go look at it sources". This is not API, nor is it a ready-to-use feature. No matter how we implement this feature, we need to be clear on the accepted input.

I think we all agreed that we should have a JSON schema to validate user data against. Given that, we can oblige the operators to feed ironic with network_data.json which must be compliant with the official schema.

The design choice being discussed is server-side vs client-side validation.

> What we absolutely cannot do is say "we use something called glean as a backend, we don't know what it accepts, go look at it sources". This is not API, nor is it a ready-to-use feature. No matter how we implement this feature, we need to be clear on the accepted input.

That's totally reasonable to have Glean input documented, maintained and hopefully versioned.

> Relying on client-side validation is a well-known anti-pattern and will cause immediate practical problems as well. So, say, we write it in Python. Metal3 will use it from a Go service in a container without Python.

Perhaps it depends on the scope of validation we want. If we do purely schema-based validation, that can probably be done without Python and without extra development.

However, if we want to go beyond schema validation (e.g. to ensure that given IPs belong to given network), then we'd need platform-specific tools which is prohibitively expensive to maintain. In that case I'd go for Glean-aware ironic conductor.

> Also, you still haven't mentioned what you're trying to win by moving the validation code to the client side. It won't be less code. It won't release us from backward compatibility concerns. It won't relief us from documenting the API and the format we accept. It won't make the backend choice discussion simpler. What's the point?

Getting ironic conductor involved in network-data.json processing feels unnecessary rigid to me. I see it as a communication path between the operator and the OS running ramdisk (you consider OS being part of ironic because of image-builder). In that light, I have a feeling that making this path dependent on ironic conductor middleman can cause nuisances in the future.

I do not have anything concrete atm, just vague concerns. For example:

* As Glean schema evolves, ironic conductor configuration or code update will be required
* If cloud-init format evolves independently from Glean, the operator can hit ironic validation failures if they attempt to use the same network_data.json for ramdisk and instance bootstrapping (the Edge deployment case)
* If the operator/developer wants to experiment/debug ramdisk bootstrapping, they can hit ironic validation failures
* If the operator/developer wants to cook their own ramdisk (not IPA, just OS) for some specific network environment, they can hit ironic validation failure
* If we decide to validate instance network_data.json in the future (as a measure of improving overall deployment reliability), having instance validation externally might make more sense. Then having ramdisk validation running externally i.e. along the same lines as instance validation can be easier to grasp and use.

I am not saying that these are likely or ominous scenarios, I just have a feeling that introducing a middleman into otherwise end-ot-end communication might not be sufficiently justified.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-01-08 12:47:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28:

> The design choice being discussed is server-side vs client-side validation.

We're working on the server-side, so there's no choice. Client-side validation means no validation.

> (e.g. to ensure that given IPs belong to given network), then we'd need platform-specific tools which is prohibitively expensive to maintain

If I got you right, it can be done through the stdlib ipaddress module.

> I have a feeling that making this path dependent on ironic conductor middleman can cause nuisances in the future.

This is a broad statement, given that we're talking about a format that barely ever changes and relies on things fundamental to the modern networking.

A can counter-argument with this: if we ever decide to change the backend, the pass-through approach will make it risky. I'm not saying we will, just for the sake of discussion.

> As Glean schema evolves, ironic conductor configuration or code update will be required

You mean, IPv8, IPv12? I think we more or less agreed yesterday that only minimal incremental changes (if any at all) are expected to the schema. And we're under no obligations to support them.

> the operator can hit ironic validation failures if they attempt to use the same network_data.json for ramdisk and instance bootstrapping

And you suggest they get deploy timeouts instead? (Again, assuming the format evolves in reality)

> a middleman into otherwise end-ot-end communication

... is what the whole openstack is about."}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2020-01-08 13:00:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28:

> If I got you right, it can be done through the stdlib ipaddress module.

I am thinking of two approaches to data validation here:

1. Based purely on JSON schema. Tools exist that consume a JSON schema and a JSON document to validate. Such tools validates given JSON document against given schema. The end result is valid/invalid. I can call is "context-free" validation.

2. Based on (1) plus some ad-hoc validations we can wire-in. These add-ons base on our knowledge of problem domain.

    The example I've mentioned in this conversation was this: we know that 'ip_address' filed should contain a IPv4 address for a NIC. We also know that 'network' filed should contain an IP network to which this NIC belongs. Having these two pieces of knowledge we can come up with an ad-hoc check ensuring that given ip_address value (interpreted as a quad-dot IP) belongs to given IP network. I can call such validation as being "context-aware".

I am not saying we should necessarily do (2) because it can be expensive to maintain. However, if we chose (1), that might free us from any validation-specific development.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-01-08 13:07:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28:

(2) is actually quite simple, but I don't insist we do it (and certainly don't insist on putting it in the spec)."}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2020-01-08 13:49:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28:

While reworking the spec I've got this thought: when validating `network_data.json` at ironic conductor, should we forbid `network_data.json` properties that are only supported by `cloud-init`, and not yet supported by `Glean`?

The trade-off appears like this:

* If we allow `cloud-init`-only properties, ironic can pass effectively non-functional (or partially functional) configuration to Glean because Glean won't be able to process such properties.
* If we forbid `cloud-init`-only properties, the operator won't be able to use the same `network_data,json` for both ramdisk and instance bootstrapping.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-01-08 14:35:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28:

I think we should absolutely prevent using features that do not work, unless ignoring them is completely safe (e.g. the network_id field).'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2020-01-08 18:06:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 29.'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2020-01-08 18:06:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28:

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2020-02-04 18:03:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 32.'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2020-02-04 18:03:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 31:

(16 comments)

Thanks for your thoughtful review!

I just wanted to note that I still feel that building network_data.json (and possibly other) validation into ironic API is not the best way forward. I'd rather keep ironic neutral to whatever information comes from operator through ironic up to ramdisk.

In other words, I'd vote for moving the following arrangement from Alternatives to the spec:

  Alternatively to having operator supplying ramdisk network configuration
  as a `network_data.json` file, Ironic can also accept the entire
  `config-drive`. That would make it looking similar to instance booting (e.g.
  Ironic provision state API) and would allow for passing more files to ramdisk
  in the future.

  Alternatively to wiring `Glean` schema validation into Ironic conductor,
  operator can be asked to validate their `network_data.json` data with some
  external tool prior to submitting it to Ironic. This would relax ironic
  conductor dependency on `Glean` input requirements changes and ease
  `network_data.json` reuse for bootstrapping both ramdisk and instance."}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2020-02-04 18:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 33.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-02-04 22:49:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 31:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-25 16:24:57.000000000', 'message': "Update L3 based deployment spec

This change proposes simplification and usability improvements
to the previous design of L3 based deployment. Proposed changes are
largely enabled by the introduction of virtual media boot capability
to `redfish` hardware type.

Among the things I'd like the reviewers to pay attention to is
how IP configuration is passed through the kernel. One limitation
I can think of is IPv6 support, the other is that VLAN interfaces
are expected to be pre-configured by the ramdisk. May be that's
something that won't work? If VLAN is important at all given
we are talking L3 here...

Change-Id: I0ac7d4301b35f88d91f46bf6ddd47080b3148ee2

commit_message:
Update L3 based deployment spec

This change proposes simplification and usability improvements
to the previous design of this spec (see Change-Id
Id6314638cc949d7e2608385728529eb0f58e838d). Proposed changes
are largely enabled by the introduction of virtual media boot
capability to `redfish` hardware type.

Related-Bug: #1749193
Change-Id: I0ac7d4301b35f88d91f46bf6ddd47080b3148ee2
Story: 2006691
Task: 36986

commit_message:
Remove ip kernel command line argument

The `ip` kernel command line argument is incompatible with newer dracut
versions used in CoreOS IPA images. A similar change was done in Ironic,
see https://review.opendev.org/#/c/566390/ for more details.

Change-Id: Ie70bba11c74b5769a7009f5b5599e41bd27e1d7c
Story: 2006700
Task: 37007
(cherry picked from commit 00d69a3f5f7521b67374fc852bad5ec970b42b7f)

commit_message:
Fix and add logs and info

This patch fixes collection of logs adding sudo to commands that
need that.
Also adds collection of some more useful info for libvirt
and qemu, for example increasing the log verbosity of libvirt.

Reordered commands to divide them by section.

Change-Id: I86ae0dac8de63449405012a99ddf94f915b304b0

commit_message:
CentOS 8 support

* Support Python 3
* Use Open vSwitch from Delorean master in CI
* Add a tenks-deploy-teardown-centos8 CI job

Depends-On: https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-role-libvirt-host/pull/26
Depends-On: https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-role-libvirt-vm/pull/53

Change-Id: Ibd504389523bf1197aa5f7c3e9ef6cad8966ddc2

commit_message:
Create a new job to call Ranger RMS service

This patch creates a new job which will call Ranger RMS service
post deployment.  The service call request Ranger to create a
region for the deployed site.

Change-Id: I03398453f579de5d2da5cf188b4779be527c3f5f

[{'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2020-03-09 14:38:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2020-03-09 14:40:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

We don't like capping and should persue alternatives (via the issue you linked for instance) first.  We can mask the known bad release in the mean time.

Is the actively causing problems for you now?"}, {'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2020-03-09 15:15:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes. it is. Devstack stack.sh is failing because of it.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2020-03-09 15:26:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Skipping just this version won't resolve the problem -- it's not a bug in setuptools, they've literally removed code I believe? We need to fix the other libs that are having problems, because the second setuptools==46.0.1 is released, this problem reappears, which could even be minutes/hours? I don't see the point of merging this as-is."}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-03-11 08:30:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

all py3-enabled branches require this now'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-11 09:53:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

 > second setuptools==46.0.1 is released, this problem reappears,
 > which could even be minutes/hours? I don't see the point of merging
 > this as-is.

+1 - this is a very temporary sticking plaster. pyscss has not been released in 4 years, so my money is on setuptools releasing first."}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-03-11 18:09:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > Skipping just this version won't resolve the problem -- it's not

 > > second setuptools==46.0.1 is released, this problem reappears,
 > > which could even be minutes/hours? I don't see the point of
 > merging
 > > this as-is.
 > 
 > +1 - this is a very temporary sticking plaster. pyscss has not been
 > released in 4 years, so my money is on setuptools releasing first.

+1"}]

commit_message:
Skip setuptools 46.0.0

setuptools 46.0.0 contradicts pyScss 1.3.4 because 'Feature' were deprecated.
Please see https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/2017

Change-Id: Iafab38336daf5d84ef9e19248b59adccfacc29ec

commit_message:
Remove ip kernel command line argument

The `ip` kernel command line argument is incompatible with newer dracut
versions used in CoreOS IPA images. A similar change was done in Ironic,
see https://review.opendev.org/#/c/566390/ for more details.

Change-Id: Ie70bba11c74b5769a7009f5b5599e41bd27e1d7c
Story: 2006700
Task: 37007
(cherry picked from commit 00d69a3f5f7521b67374fc852bad5ec970b42b7f)

messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2020-03-10 15:14:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2020-03-10 15:34:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2020-03-11 11:26:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-10 15:14:59.000000000', 'message': "Adapt FFWD2 Undercloud upgrade workflow.

In theory, in this FFWD iteration (Queens to Train) it won't
be needed to perform an Undercloud upgrade sequentially. Therefore
we don't need to build the same script to upgrade the undercloud
three times. Instead, we will make use of the very same script
used to upgrade the undercloud in updates and upgrades.

This patch also removes some unnecessary playbooks from the last
FFWD and splits the scripts creation into undercloud and overcloud
scripts creation plays and moves the configure_uc_containers.yaml
playbook into the common/ folder so it can be used by the
fast-forward-upgrade and upgrades workflows.

Change-Id: I975fc0c5bf25681bb944415eaccd3a0672998d01
(cherry picked from commit 35f820f857ef47d202320f15d1f8d2d78d85ce6e)
"}]
commit_message:
Adapt FFWD2 Undercloud upgrade workflow.

In theory, in this FFWD iteration (Queens to Train) it won't
be needed to perform an Undercloud upgrade sequentially. Therefore
we don't need to build the same script to upgrade the undercloud
three times. Instead, we will make use of the very same script
used to upgrade the undercloud in updates and upgrades.

This patch also removes some unnecessary playbooks from the last
FFWD and splits the scripts creation into undercloud and overcloud
scripts creation plays and moves the configure_uc_containers.yaml
playbook into the common/ folder so it can be used by the
fast-forward-upgrade and upgrades workflows.

Change-Id: I975fc0c5bf25681bb944415eaccd3a0672998d01
(cherry picked from commit 35f820f857ef47d202320f15d1f8d2d78d85ce6e)

commit_message:
Bump ansible version constraints to >=2.7,<2.10

This means that ansible 2.9 is typically used, and causes ansible-lint
to fail. Two workarounds have been added to address this:

* Use .get() to avoid passing an undefined object through to_nice_yaml
  filter
* Create a dummy tenks_update_state.py module to avoid ansible-lint
  being confused about our action plugin.

Change-Id: I54388f713e17a47601be2db63a26fc43ca7ac6c8

[{'created': '2020-02-24 13:23:49.000000000', 'message': 'Add basic molecule tests for uncovered roles

This patch adds basic molecule tests which fail until developers create
real ones. The molecule jobs are, of course, non-voting on the check and
not present on the gate. This way, the reminder will be haunting the
damned developers who prefer doing new things, sexier than doing important
molecule tests!

Change-Id: I7ff9506fed0fe4f00e80ff476189f9ea103d81d7
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add basic molecule tests for uncovered roles

This patch adds basic molecule tests which fail until developers create
real ones. The molecule jobs are, of course, non-voting on the check and
not present on the gate. This way, the reminder will be haunting the
damned developers who prefer doing new things, sexier than doing important
molecule tests!

Change-Id: I7ff9506fed0fe4f00e80ff476189f9ea103d81d7
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2a89e16cfeac23cce11c181f7097f8dead3ad92e)

commit_message:
Pin virtualbmc to <2 when using Python 2

This is necessary until we drop support for CentOS 7.

Also use Train upper constraints with Python 2, since Train is the last
release to support Python 2.

Change-Id: I085d107ae2d338a7609dececb7b62555937b7b1e

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1804224'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-06 13:12:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-10 11:18:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-10 13:20:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-10 14:15:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Use of advanced virt repo didn't help - https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_3f2/711416/4/check/bifrost-integration-tinyipa-centos-8/3f24cda/logs/libvirtd.log

This makes me wonder what we are doing differently in tenks to make this work."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-10 14:18:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Use of advanced virt repo didn't help - https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_3f2/711416/4/check/bifrost-integration-tinyipa-centos-8/3f24cda/logs/libvirtd.log
 > 
 > This makes me wonder what we are doing differently in tenks to make
 > this work.

tenks libvirt XML:

<domain type='qemu'>
  <name>tk0</name>
  <memory>1048576</memory>
  <vcpu>1</vcpu>
    <clock sync="localtime"/>
    <on_poweroff>destroy</on_poweroff>
  <on_reboot>restart</on_reboot>
  <on_crash>destroy</on_crash>
  <os>
    <type arch='x86_64' machine='pc'>hvm</type>
    <bootmenu enable='no'/>
    <boot dev='hd'/>
    <boot dev='cdrom'/>
    <boot dev='network'/>
    <bios useserial='yes'/>
  </os>
  <features>
    <acpi/>
    <apic/>
    <pae/>
  </features>
    <devices>
    <emulator>/usr/libexec/qemu-kvm</emulator>
    <disk type='volume' device='disk'>
      <driver name='qemu' type='qcow2'/>
            <source pool='tenks' volume='tk0vol0'/>
                  <target dev='vda' />
          </disk>
    <interface type='direct'>
      <source dev='p-tk0-0-tap' mode='passthrough'/>
                        <model type='virtio'/>
    </interface>
    <serial type='file'>
      <source path='/var/log/tenks//tk0-console.log'/>
    </serial>
    <serial type='pty'/>
    <console type='file'>
      <source path='/var/log/tenks//tk0-console.log'/>
      <target type='serial'/>
    </console>
    <rng model="virtio"><backend model="random">/dev/urandom</backend></rng>
  </devices>
</domain>'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-10 14:24:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-10 14:40:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-10 15:36:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-10 17:10:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

bifrost-integration-dhcp-ubuntu-bionic often fails with this:

OSError: [Errno 28] No space left on device

bifrost-integration-dhcp-centos-8 is doing the same, suggesting it might sometimes pass.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-10 17:10:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-03-11 14:44:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

*sigh*

At least the jobs complete. Sadness about kvm though, but c'est la vie."}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2020-03-11 15:33:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}]

- installing package trousers to add tss user and group
  needed by libvirt
- Stop setting CPU mode - allow libvirt to select. host-model was failing on
  libvirt 4.5.0 on CentOS 8 due to
  https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1804224

Change-Id: I9488dcb8af70ea06de37ffec94620f8681c21944

commit_message:
Make centos8 job vote again

Giving centos8 tinyipa vote rights again.

Fixing up some of the test scripts for CentOS 8.

- kvm_stats util has been moved to kernel-tools, the package
  qemu-kvm-tools doesn't exist anymore
- qemu-system-x86 doesn't exist anymore, therefore we run
  /usr/libexec/qemu-kvm instead of /bin/qemu-system-x86_64
- installing package trousers to add tss user and group
  needed by libvirt
- Stop setting CPU mode - allow libvirt to select. host-model was failing on
  libvirt 4.5.0 on CentOS 8 due to
  https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1804224

Change-Id: I9488dcb8af70ea06de37ffec94620f8681c21944

commit_message:
Fix Octavia client for API endpoint 503

In some deployments the Octavia API is behind a load balancer.
This load balancer may directly return an HTTP 503 status code
error to the client.
Prior to this patch, the client would not handle this situation
correctly and would return a cryptic error message:
'Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)'.

This patch updates the client to handle these types of errors
better by returning a better error message such as
"Service Unavailble".

Change-Id: Ib5e4e6ba698ec58774df20dfb8903c99ac2f0917
Story: 2007404
Task: 39004

Fixed the queries to retrieve the segment ID allocations when service
plugin network_segment_range is enabled. With the previous
implementation, a project user was able to allocate a segment ID
belonging to other project segment range.

The solution implemented was discussed in [1]:
- A project user will retrieve segments from the project ranges.

  range, never using another project segment ID.

commit_message:
Fix queries to retrieve allocations with network_segment_range

Fixed the queries to retrieve the segment ID allocations when service
plugin network_segment_range is enabled. With the previous
implementation, a project user was able to allocate a segment ID
belonging to other project segment range.

The solution implemented was discussed in [1]:
- A project user will retrieve segments from the project ranges.
- When depleted, the segment IDs will be retrieved from the shared
  range, never using another project segment ID.

[1]http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-February/012736.html

Change-Id: I953062d9ee8ee5ee9a9f07aff4a8222ac63ed525
Closes-Bug: #1863423

commit_message:
Fix os-keypairs pagination links

The API URL is '/os-keypairs', not '/keypairs'. Attempting to use these
pagination links as-is will result in a HTTP 404 (Not Found).

Conflicts:
	nova/api/openstack/compute/views/keypairs.py

NOTE(stephenfin): Conflict due to absence of change
I2820143b7b5b6f74a6c3ca67a5c9d0980e3e9a86, which we don't want to
backport.

Change-Id: Ic04568caecc138e6016418f6878d031c4a0d3fb4
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-bug: #1866373
(cherry picked from commit f31efe0a0e3f194ca415ac41c225f63dbb69267b)

commit_message:
Remove ip kernel command line argument

The `ip` kernel command line argument is incompatible with newer dracut
versions used in CoreOS IPA images. A similar change was done in Ironic,
see https://review.opendev.org/#/c/566390/ for more details.

Change-Id: Ie70bba11c74b5769a7009f5b5599e41bd27e1d7c
Story: 2006700
Task: 37007

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-10 12:54:17.000000000', 'message': "Make reservation checks caseless

If a conductor hostname is changed while reservations are
issued to a conductor with one hostname, such as 'hostName'
and then the process is restarted with 'hostname', then the
queries would not match the node and effectively the nodes
would become inaccessible until the reservation is cleared.

This patch changes the queries to use a case insenitive
like search, better known as ilike.

Special thanks to the nova team for finding a bug in the hash
ring calculation in the ironic virt driver where a customer
changed their nova-compute hostname, which inspired this
patch.

Change-Id: Ib7da925ba5ca6a82ba542e0f4ae4cf7f0d070835
(cherry picked from commit ae3a14e65c81f48472040a086075b63ca1ce76ac)
"}]
commit_message:
Make reservation checks caseless

If a conductor hostname is changed while reservations are
issued to a conductor with one hostname, such as 'hostName'
and then the process is restarted with 'hostname', then the
queries would not match the node and effectively the nodes
would become inaccessible until the reservation is cleared.

This patch changes the queries to use a case insenitive
like search, better known as ilike.

Special thanks to the nova team for finding a bug in the hash
ring calculation in the ironic virt driver where a customer
changed their nova-compute hostname, which inspired this
patch.

Change-Id: Ib7da925ba5ca6a82ba542e0f4ae4cf7f0d070835
(cherry picked from commit ae3a14e65c81f48472040a086075b63ca1ce76ac)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-11 10:32:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix microversion negotiation in some bare metal node call

Using utils.pick_microversion means that the result may be None,
which is likely lower than a version negotiated for the resource.

For example, when calling set_node_provision_state(<node name>, "provide"),
it is determined that "provide" does not require a non-default microversion,
so None is used, breaking using node name.

This change switches set_node_provision_state, set_node_power_state and
patch_node to _assert_microversion_for that takes into account the
microversion negotiated for the resource.

Change-Id: Ia81d8a39ca1c8407c689e7d128ace82071b52a01
'}, {'created': '2020-03-11 11:50:26.000000000', 'message': 'Fix microversion negotiation in some bare metal node call

it is determined that "provide" does not require a non-default microversion,
so None is used, breaking using node name.

This change switches set_node_provision_state, set_node_power_state and
patch_node to _assert_microversion_for that takes into account the
microversion negotiated for the resource.

Change-Id: Ia81d8a39ca1c8407c689e7d128ace82071b52a01

commit_message:
Fix microversion negotiation in some bare metal node call

Using utils.pick_microversion means that the result may be None,
which is likely lower than a version negotiated for the resource.

For example, when calling set_node_provision_state(<node name>, "provide"),
it is determined that "provide" does not require a non-default microversion,
so None is used, breaking using node name.

This change switches set_node_provision_state, set_node_power_state and
patch_node to _assert_microversion_for that takes into account the
microversion negotiated for the resource.

Change-Id: Ia81d8a39ca1c8407c689e7d128ace82071b52a01

commit_message:
pin ceph packages to release o=Ubuntu on rocky/bionic

When you're installing ceph on ubuntu/bionic, the luminous release isn't
readily available from ceph.com, and you end up pulling mimic packages
from uca instead. Fortunately luminous packages are available in the
distro repo.

apt-cache policy examples;
uca: release o=Canonical,a=bionic-updates,n=bionic-updates/rocky,c=main,b=amd64
ceph: release o=ceph.com,a=stable,n=bionic,c=main,b=amd64
ubuntu: release v=18.04,o=Ubuntu,a=bionic-backports,n=bionic,l=Ubuntu,c=main,b=amd64

Change-Id: I34cec9224e1367730ab4bed02abc499a65d9f53e

subject: Improve retrying on DB disconnects or deadlocks
messages:
[{'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-03 17:51:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-03 17:54:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

this is WIP.

open questions for the marks I left in the code:

* What about retries for *_migrate, encrypt_or_decrypt, *_lock_*, _purge_stacks?
* Shall I use @db_utils.retry_on_stale_data_error for *delete ops instead?
* The *_create ones, shall we care of possible duplicates or just wrap with retry_on_deadlock_or_dc(idempotent=False, max_retries=3) always?

Future work maybe: do not use tenacity for retrying DB operations, use the improved retrying decorator instead?

Also this work may be split for a several patches, having the 1st one to contain only the minimal change, like do infinit retries for updates only. I only brought all the code here for a preliminary review and collecting feedback and recommendations on how to proceed in general.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-03 17:56:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

just a 3280 unit tests have to be fixed :-)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-04 10:41:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-04 12:24:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-04 16:05:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-04 16:05:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-04 16:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-04 16:22:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2020-03-04 16:46:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)

I'm concerned that Heat is experiencing database stability issues and that it has not migrated to use oslo_db's enginefacade fully.  It's still using legacy patterns of calling session.begin() / sesion.begin(subtransactions=True) on its own; enginefacade is supposed to be doing this.

also, the code here seems to suggest that Heat is doing DB operations with the session *outside* of the begin() block.   I would not recommend this, as it leads to ad-hoc SQL operations being used in multiple transactions (and multiple database connections) serially.     The newer oslo_db.enginefacade was created to solve this problem and remove the work of having to keep track of "session.begin()" / "subtransactions" / etc outside of each application.


The patterns that should be in play are:

1. all database access occurs within a session.begin(): block.   using enginefacade you'd get this for free without having to deal with "subtransactions" which are a flawed concept that is mostly going away from SQLAlchemy public APIs in future releases.

2. normal retry decorators should only be on methods that are *outside* of the begin() block.  this is usually done based on the application knowing which methods are at the top of a chain of database operations.

3. if there are methods that can be dually-invoked, either inside of an existing transaction, or outside of one where they invoke it, then a retry decorator would need to use some intelligence to decide if the database transaction has started yet.   however, checking "session.transaction" is not actually how that would work, as that is only a logical block; the enginefacade would need to be consulted outside of it's own context manager to see if there is not yet a "session" in play.  To this end I've created a demonstration on how this can be done.  

The three classes of API call we can decide upon are:   1. always called outside of a DB transaction  2. always called inside a DB transaction and 3. might be called inside or outside, don't know until runtime.   

I've worked up a demonstration on how to use enginefacade fully and also to implement retry decorators that accommodate for all three classes of API function: https://gist.github.com/zzzeek/ba9b7dd75749dd62a1d6536a9f199698 

In the above script, we consult enginefacade to ask if it has yet started a transaction block or not.  This allows the calling application to no longer deal with SQLAlchemy's "subtransactions" flag which is deprecated as well as that it doesn't have to guess if the logical transaction block has started or not by interrogating SQLAlchemy internals; enginefacade provides the framework part here as SQLAlchemy is only a library, not a framework.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-05 09:28:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)

please let's consider changing the established patterns in another patches as this one only improves wrapping around the established things."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-05 09:32:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-05 09:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-05 09:38:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow-1

I would appreciate more hints for the changes needed for the methods wrapped for retries in this patch to provide that recommendation: "normal retry decorators should only be on methods that are *outside* of the begin() block.  this is usually done based on the application knowing which methods are at the top of a chain of database operations."'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-05 09:40:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

please also note that the idea of this patch was additionally to infinite retries on deadlocks of update operations to allow as well retries *within* the begin(block) but only for disconnects, omitting deadlocks.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-05 09:50:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

sorry, I meant ofc retrying open transactions on disconnects only, not on deadlocks'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2020-03-05 15:09:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-05 15:49:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-10 14:07:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-11 15:55:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

this is abandoned for the preference of ongoing enginefacade based effort (see task 38953 in the linked story). Please let me know if we want this attempt continued.'}]

commit_message:
Improve retrying on DB disconnects or deadlocks

Refactor Heat sqlalchemy API for the better internal durability as the
following:

* Modify @retry_on_deadlock to support retrying both transactions and
  non-transactional operations on DB disconnect as well, if it is
  marked idempotent in the decorator.

* Also support unlimited retrying on DB deadlocks/disconnects as well
  via another parameter added for the updated @retry_on_deadlock_or_dc
  decorator.

* Make the retry decorator also supporting extra exceptions for custom
  retrying logic. Wrap with it, when creating stack locks, instead of
  calling oslo.db API directly.

* Make get/reset/update/delete sqlalchemy API methods, including
  stealing and releasing locks, retrying infinitly on deadlocks and
  disconnects, also if wrapping non-transactional operations.

* Extend the original behavior to the methods creating new things:
  not retrying on dc (non-idempotent), max retries limits retained.

* Methods w/o context (required for the decorator can be used there):
  * wrap purge_deleted the same way as we do for _purge_stacks
    to call oslo.db API directly.
  * swap context and session for _get_batch to match the wrapper's
    args, remove unused session param.

Story: 2007328
task: 38849

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/711221
Change-Id: I43586ca1fac79185ec60640f089d0e065d14bc1c
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Disable alias for icons in httpd

Because we don't need /icons path accessible for all wsgi servers,
disalbe it so that we don't need to expose unnecessory files
on the node.

Change-Id: If661044ff5e113b4f18ff0d3f8d14c9d6c0024e2
Closes-Bug: #1854442

commit_message:
Remove unavailable repos from update

update_repos can contain repos which are unavailable,
so detect unavailable repos and update update_repos,
also stdout the unavailable repos which are filtered out.

Closes-Bug: #1865459
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/710727/
Change-Id: I6560836e9ec67ee40b7211f0df6cee96785ae538

commit_message:
Explicitly set --bindir when isntalling bundle

... so that we can make sure that bundle command is installed in
GEM_HOME/bin directory.

Change-Id: I1ea78bbd2b7fe22d510e10b0c96c0ed7bdc9f8a3
Closes-Bug: #1866176
(cherry picked from commit 0be086fef570892654e288b086ab175df418fa72)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-09 11:28:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix HAProxy monitor VIP precheck

If haproxy is running somewhere in the cluster and listening on the VIP,
but not running locally, then the following precheck may fail:

   TASK [haproxy : Checking free port for HAProxy monitor (vip interface)]

   msg: Timeout when waiting for 192.0.2.10:61313 to stop.

This change fixes the issue by skipping the check if HAProxy is running
on any host.

Change-Id: I831eb2f700ef3fcf65b7e08382c3b4fcc4ce8d8d
Closes-Bug: #1866617
'}, {'created': '2020-03-11 09:57:35.000000000', 'message': 'Fix HAProxy monitor VIP precheck

If haproxy is running somewhere in the cluster and listening on the VIP,
but not running locally, then the following precheck may fail:

   TASK [haproxy : Checking free port for HAProxy monitor (vip interface)]

   msg: Timeout when waiting for 192.0.2.10:61313 to stop.

This change fixes the issue by skipping the check if HAProxy is running
on any host.

Change-Id: I831eb2f700ef3fcf65b7e08382c3b4fcc4ce8d8d
Closes-Bug: #1866617
(cherry picked from commit 93a4dcc1b97b1d7bbd3b91cc9c4bd4617ec6f9ba)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix HAProxy monitor VIP precheck

If haproxy is running somewhere in the cluster and listening on the VIP,
but not running locally, then the following precheck may fail:

   TASK [haproxy : Checking free port for HAProxy monitor (vip interface)]

   msg: Timeout when waiting for 192.0.2.10:61313 to stop.

This change fixes the issue by skipping the check if HAProxy is running
on any host.

Change-Id: I831eb2f700ef3fcf65b7e08382c3b4fcc4ce8d8d
Closes-Bug: #1866617
(cherry picked from commit 93a4dcc1b97b1d7bbd3b91cc9c4bd4617ec6f9ba)

commit_message:
lsyncd: use relative paths in exclude statement

It seems only relative paths should be used in the exclude
statement. This has probably gone unnoticed since there is a second
sync for these files.

Change-Id: Ife4c1ab05e135930da8706d96af5b23648cee800

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-06 20:46:11.000000000', 'message': "Make _get_undercloud_host_entry(self) python3 friendly

On CentOS8 we can fail with:

    unable to pull image: Error initializing source docker://undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787/rh-osbs/rhosp16-openstack-cinder-volume:20200305.1: error pinging docker registry undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787: Get http://undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787/v2/: dial tcp: lookup undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local: no such host

The reason for that is a wrong entry in /etc/hosts:
$  grep undercloud-0 controller-0/etc/hosts
b'192.168.24.1 undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local undercloud-0.ctlplane\n'

The reason for this is that we invoked 'getent hosts' without passing
'universal_newlines=True' to subprocess.Popen()

Tested this and I correctly get past the issue that was observed
(seen for the first time via rhbz#1810898)

Change-Id: I2f13885a3056dd7690e9a00e2b1f7bc6aa78fff7
Closes-Bug: #1866313
(cherry picked from commit bba24caafcdfd7d450b29c00bdb81e518ba9b5f3)
"}]
commit_message:
Make _get_undercloud_host_entry(self) python3 friendly

On CentOS8 we can fail with:

    unable to pull image: Error initializing source docker://undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787/rh-osbs/rhosp16-openstack-cinder-volume:20200305.1: error pinging docker registry undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787: Get http://undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787/v2/: dial tcp: lookup undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local: no such host

The reason for that is a wrong entry in /etc/hosts:
$  grep undercloud-0 controller-0/etc/hosts
b'192.168.24.1 undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local undercloud-0.ctlplane\n'

The reason for this is that we invoked 'getent hosts' without passing
'universal_newlines=True' to subprocess.Popen()

Tested this and I correctly get past the issue that was observed
(seen for the first time via rhbz#1810898)

Change-Id: I2f13885a3056dd7690e9a00e2b1f7bc6aa78fff7
Closes-Bug: #1866313
(cherry picked from commit bba24caafcdfd7d450b29c00bdb81e518ba9b5f3)

commit_message:
Use blockinfile for hosts file generation

This patch aims to simplify generation of hosts
file content as it's now generated purely with ansible.

As a result upgrade jobs should be fixed afterwards

Change-Id: I7961115f215153515ba3f3a00bbbeeb9fb4568f1

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7353, 'name': 'Kevin Carter', 'email': 'kevin@cloudnull.com', 'username': 'cloudnull'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24245, 'name': 'Harald Jensås', 'email': 'hjensas@redhat.com', 'username': 'harald.jensas'}, {'_account_id': 25877, 'name': 'Luke Short', 'email': 'ekultails@gmail.com', 'username': 'ekultails'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-10 22:52:36.000000000', 'message': 'Fail when there are no nodes to introspect

The mistral workflow would fail when no nodes were in a manageable
state to introspect. This change replicates that behaviour.

One of the causes of bug #1866204 is that there is a reliance on the
time it takes to to the introspect for the node segment mappings to
populate. When introspect finishes instantly, provide ends up timing
out because the port create fails.

Change-Id: I8a27a098b3cd006f73c33d95f2d93c65cf629203
Closes-Bug: #1866911
Related-Bug: #1866204
'}]
commit_message:
Fail when there are no nodes to introspect

The mistral workflow would fail when no nodes were in a manageable
state to introspect. This change replicates that behaviour.

One of the causes of bug #1866204 is that there is a reliance on the
time it takes to to the introspect for the node segment mappings to
populate. When introspect finishes instantly, provide ends up timing
out because the port create fails.

Change-Id: I8a27a098b3cd006f73c33d95f2d93c65cf629203
Closes-Bug: #1866911
Related-Bug: #1866204

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-02 14:46:57.000000000', 'message': "Fix placement DB migration

While placement extraction, mysql-migrate-db.sh script is launched,
which creates mysql dump of tables from nova and
completes data import into placement DB.
To do such dump script needs appropriate permissions to create
directory and dump itself.
So running chdir to ensure that it won't be a problem.

Change-Id: I76238f8b59594839ff557dd1053d4a7f9a157718
"}]
commit_message:
Fix placement DB migration

While placement extraction, mysql-migrate-db.sh script is launched,
which creates mysql dump of tables from nova and
completes data import into placement DB.
To do such dump script needs appropriate permissions to create
directory and dump itself.
So running chdir to ensure that it won't be a problem.

Change-Id: I76238f8b59594839ff557dd1053d4a7f9a157718

to get them back readable via a browser.

commit_message:
Stop gzipping logs in get-logs.sh

As per [1] we should stop compressing the logs sent to swift in order
to get them back readable via a browser.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-January/011875.html

Change-Id: Ieb1577f859d388a0f326cb6933c953f486dfca15
Co-Authored-By: Michal Nasiadka <mnasiadka@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-11 07:30:33.000000000', 'message': 'Add a firewall rule for rabbitmq CLI tools

In recent rabbitmq, the CLI tools requires an access to 35672-35682.
The lack of the rules causes some commands(e.g. rabbitmqctl list_queues)
cannot get the full result.

Change-Id: I19c9dd32f25262890c3ed042a2bd976bfffa9568
Closes-Bug: #1866958
'}]
commit_message:
Add a firewall rule for rabbitmq CLI tools

In recent rabbitmq, the CLI tools requires an access to 35672-35682.
The lack of the rules causes some commands(e.g. rabbitmqctl list_queues)
cannot get the full result.

Change-Id: I19c9dd32f25262890c3ed042a2bd976bfffa9568
Closes-Bug: #1866958

commit_message:
Swift: remove meta field from rsync command

Remove the {meta} from the default settings in the account, container
and object services templates.

Change-Id: I079fddf8feb020bed93bf44b8aaec0882823e15c
Closes-Bug: #1862058
